Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Progressive Responses to Climate Change Across Multiple Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates how four different terrestrial ecosystems from the southwestern US, from high desert grassland to subalpine prairie, respond to increased temperature and altered precipitation, using experimental treatments that simulate the expected future climate in 100 years. These treatments have been imposed for nearly a decade and are planned to continue for a decade more, creating a long-term climate change experiment across multiple ecosystem types. The goals of this project are to test whether the initial responses of these ecosystems to simulated climate change are consistent over time, or whether they change over time as the ecosystems adjust to the new climatic conditions. The responses that will be documented include plant growth, carbon cycling and storage, and soil release of greenhouse gases like methane and nitrous oxide.

This project is important because climate change affects terrestrial ecosystems, but also because these ecosystems affect climate. Therefore, how ecosystems respond will influence the pace and trajectory of future changes in the climate system. The project fills a key knowledge gap, because long-term responses of ecosystems to climate change are especially important for understanding the future climate, but these responses are difficult to document, requiring experiments that last for decades. The project will integrate global change research with science education through provision of competitive undergraduate internships. Outreach activities organized through local conservation organizations will place this research in a broad context accessible to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. How do different ecosystems respond to environmental change? Are their responses consistent over time, or do they change, initially responding in one way, and later responding in another way? And why might these changes over time occur? This project examined these questions using a unique and simple approach of transplanting ecosystems down in elevation, exposing them now to their future climates. The main advantage of this approach are that it is realistic, exposing both above-ground and below-ground parts of the ecosystem to the novel climate, and that it is cost-effective, requiring far less funding to support in the long term. This project examined responses of four ecosystems to long-term climate change treatments from 2002 through 2015. The project's main finding was climate change initially boosted plant growth, but the effect declined over time (see the third figure). This occured because the climate change treatments altered the types of plant species that were present in the plots, and because climate change altered nitrogen cycling - but both of these responses took time to develop. The change in plant species took time, because of the lifespan of the plants involved, and the pace at which they're able to move from one place to another. The change in the nitrogen cycle took time, because ecosystems store large quantities of nitrogen that cycles at different rates, so it takes a while for the nitrogen cycle of the whole system to catch up to rapid change in climate that occurred at the beginning of the experiment. These changes hold valuable and important lessons as we consider how ecosystems respond to climate change, and how those responses shape the future of the atmosphere and climate system. Land ecosystems store tremendous amounts of carbon, and they exchange that carbon with the atmosphere at rates governed by the activities of plants and microorganisms. This experiment has shown how some of the controls over those rates are sensitive to climate change, and how that sensitivity strongly depends on time.

This project supported other experiments that took advantage of the long-term climate change treatments. In one project, researchers explored the sensitivity of ecosystem carbon storage to short-term bursts of carbon inputs, much like what happens as plants grow and deposit carbon into the soil. A strange phenomenon often follows these pulses of carbon input - not only do the microorganisms in soil consume the carbon pulse, they also increase their consumption of older soil organic matter, organic matter that was already present in the ecosystem to begin with, but that microbes did not use, presumably because it is more difficult to decompose (one analogy for this strange phenomenon is, it's as if feeding appetizers to guests caused them to start eating the furniture). The research conducted here showed that this "priming" phenomenon is sensitive to climate change, though only in certain ecosystems. This finding has implications for how we microorganisms will influence the soil carbon sink in the future, again with feedbacks to the climate system because of the large size of the soil carbon reservoir. 

 

Broader Impacts. This project supported a number of developing scientists, trained them in state-of-the-art research techniques and in the general field of ecology and ecosystem sciences. Among the four undergraduates who conducted research associated with this project, three are currently pursuing PhDs in ecology and related fields, one at the Unviersity of Arizona, one at the University of Hawaii, and one at Northern Arizona.
